awd_titl_txt: Transitory Stochastic Models: Analysis and Optimization
awd_abstract_narration:
Stochastic models are widely used to analyze and optimize healthcare, communication, large-scale computing, and transportation systems. Existing theory has tended to focus on easier-to-analyze homogeneous models that assume that service requirements are identical for all users. Recent technological trends have made it possible to collect large amounts of data that show that users' requirements are often heterogeneous. Thus, a theory of nonhomogeneous stochastic models is needed. The goal of this project is develop a theory of 'transitory stochastic models' that explicitly incorporates users' inhomogeneity and, concomitantly, considers the optimization and control of these models. If successful, this project will contribute to the theoretical understanding of nonhomogeneous stochastic systems, and the application of the theoretical results can potentially result in significant performance gains in the operational management of many service systems. Furthermore, ideas from this project will be incorporated into a new stochastic modeling course for undergraduates that integrates theory, data modeling and optimization. The PI will also leverage summer research programs to facilitate research experiences for minority and female undergraduate students.

The theoretical objective of this research is to develop stochastic process and analytical approximations for the performance analysis and optimization of transitory stochastic models. The models considered include systems with many servers, queueing networks, and systems with heavy-tailed service times and non-stationary, correlated traffic. The systems are transitory in the sense that we are interested in predictions over a finite, but operationally significant time horizon, and the models require a purely transient analysis, which is non-trivial even in the simpler cases. The research has twin related foci: first, this effort will identify novel scaling regimes in which "universal" stochastic process approximations to the traffic and workload processes can be established, in the form of functional central limit theorems, strong approximations and conditioned limit theorems. Second, the research will also consider the identification of optimal controls for the underlying systems using these stochastic process approximations. The focus here will be on developing analytical approximations to the expected cost functions and identifying an accompanying notion of asymptotic optimality of controls.

por.por_cntn:
This project developed new mathematical models and introduced new analyses of mathematical models of service operations. Service operations, such as in healthcare, logistics and transportation systems, are important arbiters of modern life. Therefore, predicting and improving levels of operational efficiency and cost effectiveness of these systems is crucial for the national welfare and economic prosperity of the United States. This effort is the focus of operations research broadly, and this project in particular. Service systems almost always operate in environments that are time-varying (for instance, the demand for taxi or shared-cab rides is time-of-day or day-of-week dependent) and often in environments that vary randomly (the demand for taxis or shared cab rides in a particular location is also influenced by the weather and other random effects). In these settings, system prediction and improvement is a particularly hard exercise, and yet it is precisely because of these time- and random-variations that these exercises are of paramount importance. For both prediction and improvement, policy makers, engineers and managers of these systems require sophisticated mathematical tools. Standard mathematical tools, however, are often inadequate to the task since these temporally- and randomly-varying are not explicitly modeled, or the modeling is highly stylized. 

This project makes several contributions towards the development of mathematical tools for modeling, analyzing and improving service operations in time-varying and random environments. First, the project developed a new phenomenological model of service demand. The project also developed accompanying mathematical results for predicting operational efficiency using this phenomenological model. Standard models in operations research tend to be mechanistic in nature, and consequently even though service systems exist to serve individual customers and operations are determined by the behavior of individual customers, it becomes very hard to interpret mechanistic models in terms of the behavior of the individuals. This distinction between mechanistic and phenomenological models is particularly crucial while improving operational efficiency and cost effectiveness by influencing individual customer behavior. This project studied and analyzed a specific system design problem (optimally scheduling patient appointments at a clinic to ensure minimal wait time and maximizing cost effectiveness) that highlights and illustrates the substantial advantages afforded by the phenomenological model. This specific study has also spurred further intellectual developments to understand the mathematics underlying system design using the phenomenological model. The project further investigated service systems operating in random environments and whether the phenomenological models are appropriate to use in this setting. This investigation showed that the latter were not appropriate, but also yielded new insights into how to model and analyze service systems operating in random environments. The additional complexity of these models required new analyses that show how the predictions of operational efficiency are influenced by the random environment. These insights were not previously available in the literature. Finally, the project also investigated how models of service systems operating in time-varying and random environments, and the phenomenological model in particular, can be estimated from operational data.

The results of this project have been communicated broadly to interested research communities through presentations at top conferences and by publishing papers in top journals and conference proceedings. These papers are available to the public. The results of this project have also been incorporated into the PIs courses. Furthermore, the project has also spurred the development of a cross-disciplinary research team consisting of mathematicians and industrial engineers/operations researchers  focused on understanding and improving service operations. These are long-term relationships that will spur further innovations and intellectual developments. The intellectual products and outcomes of the project also provide policy-makers, operations engineers and managers new tools and results to predict and improve service system operational efficiencies and cost effectiveness. The intellectual products have contributed to the foundational understanding of the mathematics of service operations. It is anticipated that this will provide a basis for further innovations and developments by practitioners, academicians and policy-makers in the future.
